If cornerstone investors exist, the AI should state that cornerstone subscriptions form part of the International Placing and disclose cornerstone share quantities and lock-up restrictions (commonly six months), using prospectus-style language.

Pricing mechanism and price determination

The AI should explain that the final offer price is determined within the indicated offer price range, typically based on bookbuilding results and agreement between the Company and Joint Global Coordinators.

The output should emphasize that all investors in both tranches pay the same final offer price and should include timing references for the pricing date and announcement of results where the prospectus framework requires it.

Conditions for completion and refund logic

The AI should list key offering conditions, including sufficient subscription under the Hong Kong tranche, non-termination of underwriting, and listing approval.

The AI should state that if conditions are not satisfied, the Global Offering will not proceed and application monies will be refunded, using standard formal phrasing.

Impact of over-allotment option on structure

The AI should explain how exercise of the over-allotment option may increase the total number of shares in issue and may affect final allocation and share capital.

The disclosure should state that the Company will announce whether the option is exercised and that post-offering share capital figures may change accordingly.

Allocation basis and publication of results

The AI should explain that Hong Kong Public Offering allocations are typically determined by ballot/draw if oversubscribed, and results are published through specified channels, while International Placing allocations are determined by underwriters based on bookbuilding allocation principles.

The AI should emphasize fairness and compliance with public float requirements, referencing standard minimum public float expectations where the prospectus framework includes such statements.

Listing, trading, and settlement arrangements

The AI should provide listing and trading details such as expected listing date, stock code, board lot size, and settlement method.

The output should mention that shares will be admitted into CCASS and will settle through CCASS arrangements, and should clarify whether physical share certificates are issued or whether settlement is primarily electronic, consistent with the offering structure.

Investor valueBy explaining tranche structure, pricing logic, clawback mechanics, allocation process, and settlement arrangements in an accessible but precise way, this section enables investors to understand how the offering works and what determines their chance of allocation and trading readiness post-listing.

sections.section: How to Apply for Hong Kong Offer Shares
sections.content:
PurposeThis section provides procedural guidance to investors who wish to apply for Hong Kong Offer Shares in the Hong Kong Public Offering, including eligibility, application channels, payment requirements, timelines, and post-application arrangements.

FormatThe AI should draft this section as step-by-step procedural instructions with clear sub-headings and numbered steps where appropriate. The language must be direct, operational, and compliance-consistent, ensuring investors can follow the process correctly without ambiguity.

Eligibility and basic rules

The AI should state who is eligible to apply and the basic application restrictions, including the “one application per applicant” rule and prohibitions on multiple or duplicate applications.

The output should clarify that invalid, duplicate, or ineligible applications may be rejected, and should include the common rule that an applicant and joint applicants together may submit only one application.

Where age or identification requirements are part of the standard offering documentation, the AI should state them clearly and neutrally as eligibility conditions.

Application channels overview

The AI should describe the permitted application methods and make clear that applicants should choose only one channel.

Typical channels include White Form eIPO online application, CCASS (Yellow Form) application through CCASS participants or investor participant accounts, and paper application forms if applicable.

The output should clearly separate each channel and explain that using more than one channel may constitute multiple applications and may lead to rejection.

White Form eIPO application steps

The AI should provide step-by-step guidance for White Form eIPO applications, including accessing the designated platform, entering personal details, selecting board lot multiples, arranging payment, and obtaining an application reference number.

The AI should include the opening and closing times for online application windows where such time precision is required by the prospectus framework.

CCASS (Yellow Form) application procedures

The AI should explain CCASS application procedures in two common scenarios: applying through a broker or CCASS participant, and applying directly as a CCASS Investor Participant.

The output should explain that shares allotted through CCASS applications will be credited to the applicant’s CCASS account (or held in CCASS nominee form) and that physical certificates may not be issued for such applications.

Payment and fee components

The AI should state that full payment is required at the time of application.

The output should describe the standard payment composition: application monies based on the maximum offer price (or as specified), plus brokerage commission and relevant transaction levies and trading fees, with the common “more paid will be refunded” logic.

If specific rates (e.g., brokerage commission percentage and transaction levy rates) are required, the AI should present them exactly as provided in input data and in the standard disclosure style, ensuring numerical accuracy and avoiding approximations.

Application timetable and key dates

The AI should present key timetable items for the Hong Kong Public Offering, including application opening time, application closing time, expected results announcement date, refund date, and share dispatch/crediting date, aligning with the offering timetable section.

Time precision should match prospectus requirements, using exact date and time expressions rather than vague references.

Application form completion guidance

If paper forms are used, the AI should include brief guidance on form completion (e.g., writing names clearly, joint applicant limits, submission location and deadline).

If paper forms are not used, the AI should still ensure investors understand the accuracy requirements of application details, as errors may invalidate an application.

Declarations and undertakings by applicants

The AI should list the key declarations typically made by applicants, such as confirming they have read the prospectus, provided accurate information, made only one application, and agree to accept the final offer price and allocation outcome.

This part should be written in a formal, bullet-point style that resembles standard application declarations, keeping the language close to typical prospectus legal phrasing.

Personal data statement

The AI should include a personal information collection statement explaining how applicant data will be used for identity verification, allocation, refunds, and related offering administration, and should reference Hong Kong privacy law principles, including applicants’ rights to access and correct personal data.

The tone must be formal and compliance-focused, reflecting statutory notice style.

Special arrangements and contingencies

The AI should describe special arrangements such as bad weather procedures (e.g., typhoon signal or black rainstorm warning), explaining how application deadlines may be extended and how announcements will be made.

The output should structure these contingencies clearly so applicants understand scenario triggers and resulting timetable changes.

Results announcement, refunds, and share delivery

The AI should explain how applicants can check allocation results (e.g., publication in newspapers and designated websites, identification by partial ID codes), and how refunds are processed for unsuccessful or partially successful applications.

The AI should explain how shares are delivered: physical share certificates for White Form applicants where applicable, and CCASS crediting for CCASS applicants, with clear timing and method descriptions.

The output should remind applicants of any identification requirements for in-person collection if that option exists.

Trading and post-allocation reminder

The AI should state when trading is expected to commence and remind investors that trading should only occur after results are formally announced, cautioning against speculative trading before official allocation confirmation.

The language should be short and practical, reinforcing process clarity and investor risk awareness.

Investor valueBy providing complete, step-by-step application instructions with precise deadlines, payment requirements, and post-application logistics, this section ensures retail investors can participate correctly in the Hong Kong Public Offering and understand what to expect after submitting an application.

All sections must follow structured formatting, precise terminology, and compliant disclosure language, ensuring the prospectus content is professional, accurate, and fully aligned with Hong Kong listing standards.
